Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Comment: Can be marked with Px,

Feature: Are there indefinite or non-specific articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
Comment: Can be marked with Px.

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Comment: Inversion may be in poetic language.

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Is there a distinction between inclusive and exclusive?
Is there a gender distinction in phonologically independent third person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun or person index system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in adnominal demonstratives?
Comment: There is only proximal vs. distal distinction: тайӧ 'this (here)' vs. distal сійӧ 'that (there)'.

Feature: Do adnominal demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Comment: There is only proximal vs. distal distinction: тайӧ 'this (here)' vs. distal сійӧ 'that (there)'.

Feature: Do adnominal demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Comment: There is only proximal vs. distal distinction: тайӧ 'this (here)' vs. distal сійӧ 'that (there)'.

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there a productive overt morphological singular marker on nouns?
Is there a productive morphological dual marker on nouns?
Is there a productive morphological plural marker on nouns?
Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Comment: Simple plural marker can take this function.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Comment: Usually formed with -ан. Some formations with -ӧм exist, but the latter suffix is not productive in this function.

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where masculine and feminine categories are a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor and possessed noun?
Do property words (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Do adnominal property words (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S, A or P)?
Comment: Typical case alignment: agent: nominative; direct object: nominative or accusative; indirect object: dative. In certain situations, other cases are also used.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for phonologically independent personal pronominal core arguments (i.e. S, A or P)?
Comment: Typical case alignment: agent: nominative; direct object: accusative; indirect object: dative. In certain situations, other cases are also used.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S, A or P)?
Are there morphological cases for phonologically independent oblique personal pronouns (i.e. not S, A or P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes or proclitics other than S, A or P indexes (do include indexes that also mark TAM or negation)?
Do verbs have suffixes or enclitics other than S, A or P indexes (do include indexes that also mark TAM or negation)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Comment: -а- is the non-past tense marker for 1st and 2nd person of both numbers; in 3rd person, present and future are distinguished, -ӧ- being the present tense marker. Negation verb uses a separate stem to denote non-past tense.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Comment: Only 3SG and 3PL can be marked for the future tense with the -а-; other personal endings containing this morpheme can be used to express either present or future, with no formal distinction.

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Comment: The so-called second, resultative, or evidential past tense, can only be used to refer to perfective actions. Additionally, verbal suffixes such as-ывл, -ывт, -ӧст, -л, -ысь can indicate completed actions, although in their case this meaning is implied and secondary rather than denoted.

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Is there verb suppletion for participant person?
Comment: Morphonologically conditioned в:л alternation or stem contractions may be observed in imperative and connegative forms.

Feature: Can a verb have a benefactive marker (applicative marker or index)?
Can a verb have an instrumental marker (applicative marker or index)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the transitive patient?
Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Comment: Only for the verb 'to be'.

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Comment: Suffixes -ӧд-, -т/д- is/are used for this purpose. Alternations are possible in roots whose original final consonant clusters have been simplified in their intransitive forms.

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Comment: Formed with -зь/сь, -ч-.

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Comment: Formed with -зь/сь, -ч-.

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word (‘auxiliary verb’)?
Comment: Imperatives of the verb вай can be used to mark 1PL imperative/hortative (вай тӧдмасям! вайӧй ветлам!).

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word (‘auxiliary verb’)?
Comment: Fossilised forms of the verb вӧвны 'to be' are used to mark continuous or habitual aspect along with past tense (explicit or evidential) on verbs. As they do not inflect for person, number or negation, they do not trigger 1 for this feature.

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word (‘auxiliary verb’)?
Comment: The verbs пондыны and кутны are used as auxiliaries marking future reference.

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Comment: Verbs of similar or complementary meaning can be coupled to express a generalisation or to signal a greater scope of the activity (habituality, engagement of the actor in the process, etc.).

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Comment: Coincides with predicate copula in tenses other than present and in negations in all tenses.

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. ‘to lie’ vs. ‘to stand’)?
Is there a notably small number of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Comment: The basic word order is SVO or SVX, both in main and subordinate clauses.

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Is the order of core argument (i.e. S, A, and P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Comment: Negation appears clause-initially if it is in focus.

Feature: Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Comment: -ś/ć-, in addition to being a reflexive/reciprocal suffix, is also used to form passive verbs.

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Comment: -ś/ć-, in addition to being a reflexive/reciprocal suffix, is also used to form antipassive verbs.

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signaling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause (‘switch reference’)?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Comment: There is distinction between simultaneous and sequential converbs.

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Comment: Formed with -ӧд-. The subject of a transitive verb becomes the indirect object of a ditransitive verb.

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for ‘to say’?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: Adjectives and adverbs can be reduplicated to express high intensity of the denoted trait. Numerals are reduplicated to form distributives.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological trial marker on nouns?
Is there a productive morphological paucal marker on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in noun class/gender?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in noun class/gender?
Can an article agree with the noun in noun class/gender?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any noun class/gender of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Comment: -тор is productive as a diminutive suffix (Lytkin 1955:156), -ук is another diminutive suffix, although its usage is limited to personal names.

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a noun class/gender system where a noun’s phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Is there a masculine/feminine distinction in phonologically independent second person pronouns?
Is there a masculine/feminine distinction in phonologically independent first person pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in noun class/gender?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) and the noun?
Comment: When nominalised with the definitive/possessive suffix and used in adposition, it can appear on either side of the described NP.

Feature: Do collective (‘all’) and distributive (‘every’) universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive ‘habeo’ verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Comment: A possessor is in GEN.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a comitative/conjunctional construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Comment: Russian-borrowed али, разьве and неужели are used word-initially to form polar questions.

Feature: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means ‘surpass, exceed’?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Comment: Elative is used for comparison.

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a ‘surpass/exceed’ meaning?
Comment: Besides the elative case, postpositions дорысь and серти can be used to mark comparison, but the former also has locational meaning.

Feature: Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Comment: The Russian-loaned particle бӧльӧ can be used in colloquial speech.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Comment: All ideophones are characteristically reduplicated with only partial identity of the two parts. Their usage tends to be limited to qualifying a closed set of verbs.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word (‘auxiliary verb’)?
Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word (‘auxiliary particle’)?
Does the verb for ‘give’ have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker (‘particle’ or ‘auxiliary’)?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker (‘particle’ or ‘auxiliary’)?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Comment: Instrumental can be used for this purpose, although there is a tendency to avoid it.

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive marker?
Comment: There is a reflexive pronoun, declined for all persons and cases, including core argument cases.

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reciprocal marker that does not consist of two quantifiers (e.g. each + other; two + two)?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Comment: Imperative mood has distinct forms of the negation verb and compulsory -ӧй ending in all plural forms (including the 2PL connegative). Second past tense could be interpreted as evidential.

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of noun class/gender?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of noun class/gender?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose noun class/gender is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Comment: Second past tense (with forms in -ӧм-) is used to express evidentiality. The auxiliary вӧлӧм in compound past tenses can also convey this meaning.

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there non-adjacent relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Comment: Separate names for 20, 30, 40, ... and for each order of magnitude starting with 10^2.

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for ‘see’ have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for ‘come’ have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Comment: Definite objects acquire accusative.

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Comment: Indefinite objects remain in the nominative case like the subject of the clause.

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in second person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer for complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Comment: The conjunction 'мый' is used. Russian-loaned что is also found, although it is rarer and proscribed.

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer for complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Comment: The postposition 'йылысь' can be used to introduce a complement of a verb of knowing, although it introduces a topic, not object of knowing (in this sense, it is equivalent to the English 'about').

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ('auxiliary particle')?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word (‘auxiliary particle’)?
Comment: Fossilised forms вӧлі and вӧлӧма of the verb вӧвны 'to be' are used to mark continuous or habitual aspect of past tense (explicit or evidential respectively) with verb forms of present or future tense. In these constructions the semantic verb that declines for person, number and negation; вӧлі/вӧлӧма are undeclineable so they qualify as particles.

Feature: Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word (‘auxiliary particle’)?
Comment: Fossilised forms вӧлі and вӧлӧма of the verb вӧвны 'to be' are used to mark continuous or habitual aspect of past tense (explicit or evidential respectively) with verb forms of present or future tense. In these constructions the semantic verb that declines for person, number and negation; вӧлі/вӧлӧма are undeclineable so they qualify as particles.

Feature: Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferable from context ('pro-drop')?
